description.narrative: BRA/99/G32-PIMS 0543 CC: Hydrogen Fuel Cell Buses
seat of a first-order administrative division

Development Objective: To reduce GHG emissions via the introduction of a new energy source and propulsion technology for urban buses. Immediate Objective: To demonstrate the operational viability of FC drives in urban bus and their refueling infrasctructures under Brazilian conditions.
1. CO2 emissions from SÃ£o Paulo buses decreased by 1,560 tones

comment.narrative: 0 tones
1,560 tones

13 Comments: The overall goal of reduction of CO2 emissions will not be achieved in this Project due to the reduction of the number of vehicles initially expected and delays in the construction of the buses which did not allow a longer operation period. Considering the extension of the Project until December 2015, 47 tons of CO2 avoided emissions are expected to be achieved given that the 03 new buses were launched in June 2015 and tests will be run until the end of the year.

description.narrative: 2. Buses are operated for 1,000,000 vehicle-km, that operational statistic can be gathered.

comment.narrative: 0 vehicle-km
1,000,000 vehicle-km

8,274 Comments: As explained in the MTE, the mileage goal will not be achieved in this Project given the reduction of the number of vehicles initially expected and the delays in the construction of the buses, which did not allow a longer operation period. Considering the extension of the Project until December 2015, only 30,000 vehicle-km are expected to be achieved. However, during the final evaluation, the calculation of estimated mileage from other experiences of FCB will be agregated to this indicator. By MTE, the mileage for Ballard Fuel Cell engines amounted to 3,971,608 bus-km worldwide.

description.narrative: 3. The amount of vehicle-km obtained in the prototype operation

comment.narrative: 0 vehicle-km
256,000 vehicle-km

8,274 Comments: The prototype ran 8,274 km up to date. During the last years, it faced several technical issues related to traction system and eletric components. After those were solved, the fuel cell presented problems caused by the non-use of the vehicle. The project has spare parts to change it, however, the technical teams from Bus integrator were concentrated on building the 03 new buses and could not allocate technical teams for this first task. We expect that this issue is resolved after the beginning of the tests of the 3 buses of Phase II.3 of the project.

The normal operation is expected to begin in the second half of 2015, with expected mileage of 21,600 km until December 2015.

description.narrative: Significant demonstration of the operational viability of fuel cell drives in urban buses and their refueling infrastructure under Brazilian conditions.

comment.narrative: 30,000 km per year

8,274 (accumulated) Comments: As previously mentioned, the prototype is not working at this point time since all Consortium efforts have been allocated to operation of the 03 new FCBs. The technical reports of the prototype demonstrate the reasons for non-functioning over the last years.

description.narrative: 6. Up to 4 buses operation level in km per year

comment.narrative: 0 km
40,000 km per year

0
Comments: It is expected that each bus runs around 7,200 kilometers (in average) until the end of the Project, considering the extension of the Project until December 2015. Unfortunately, given delays in building the buses, the time for testing and operations has reduced considerably. The FTE will present an analysis of delays, failures and their respective impact on timing for the buses and project as a whole. Overall, the construction of the new buses was impacted both bureaucratic issues related to importing of foreign equipment and parts, and unfavorable market conditions for the national partners of the automotive sector which affected production and resources within the industry itself.

description.narrative: 7. Refueling station operated satisfactorily to supply sufficient H2 at reasonable cost. Indicator: system availability percentage

comment.narrative:

Comments: - The hydrogen production station was inaugurated in June 2015. The functional tests of the buses of Phase II.3 were made with hydrogen already produced in the station. The Petrobras operation staff was trained by Hydrogenics and is able to operate the station. However, some adjustments are necessary in order the station is fully operational and the final milestone is reached. The required visa for technicians is being requested by the company.

description.narrative: 8. Prototype breakdown level under 20,000 km

comment.narrative: 0 km

8,274 km
Comments: The prototype ran 8,274 km and it is not operational in this PIR period because of some traction system problems, that we expect may be resolved after the beginning of the tests of the buses of Phase II.3, when the breakdown level will be evaluated. Because it is a prototype, it is expected to experience some technical problems at the operation. That being said, the breakdown level reached is not superior to the target. It should be mentioned that originally this was not caused by the fuel cell technolgy itself, but rather by auxiliary systems. The lessons learned with the prototype were incorporated into the design of the 03 new FCBs and foreign equipment was replaced by national parts to 60% of the total buses.

As assessed in the MTE, the 03 new FCB have robust technological design and it is expected that the target is achieved after the duration of this specific project.

description.narrative: BRA/07/G32 - PIMS 3280 - Mangrove Ecosystems in Brazil
seat of a first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration
A field tested protected area management strategy is adopted for the effective conservation of a representative sample of mangrove ecosystems in Brazil

1.Populations of threatened and overexploited species, selected as indicators of improved protection from threats in pilot UC
Eudocimus ruber
Ucides cordatus

Remain the same as at
Remain the same as at project outset

The project elaborated the Programme for Monitoring of Biodiversity in Federal UCs with Mangroves; it takes into consideration exploited and non-exploited species of fauna and flora in mangroves areas, and presents a cluster of Rapid Assessment Protocols (RAPs) for prioritized species (according to Secretariat of the Convention of Biological Diversity 2006, and Secretariat of Ramsar Convention, 2005, 2010). The selected species include the Eudocimus ruber (commonly denominated Guará: non-exploited) and the Ucides cordatus (commonly denominated Uçá Crab: exploited), that are mentioned in the project as indicators for conservation of biodiversity of mangroves areas.
The project elaborated ToRs and started actions for data gathering and meta-analysis: findings will be available by the end of 2015 (two specialized services have been purchased).
U. cordatus is one of the most investigated species in Conservation Units of Brazil (CUs): preliminary indicative data on stock estimation can be obtained in applied researches in the Cassurubá CU (Schmidt 2008, 2010 and 2012), and in APA CIP (Pinheiro 2013). U. Cordatus also allows to make substantial and scientific-based inferences on climate change, as it it sensitive to environmental alterations (e.g. rains, temperatures).
E. ruber is relevant as nests are only in mangrove woods, hence the nest monitoring allows to indicate effects on environmental alterations (e.g. mangrove health, pollution). Some data are available in CEMAVE/ICMBio (National Center for Research and Conservation of Wild Birds), specifically for Cururupú CU (Resex in Maranhão state), Mamanguape River CUs (APA and ARIE in Paraiba State), and in Cananeia-Iguape-Peruibe CU (APA in Sao Paulo).
Furthermore, the project started several activities in order to develop and fully implement the participatory monitoring of biodiversity (e.g. SocMon methodology, focused on social-environmental indicators), and to harmonize those tools and protocols through an appropriation process within the ICMBio (i.e. ongoing consultancy, leaded by the competent department COMOB/DIBIO/ICMBio), in order to guarantee sustainability and ownership of outputs (see outcome # 4).

There is an error in the text of the indicator. The PRI format reports the text of the indicator #1. The right text is: % of mangrove ecosystems in mangrove UCs under management categories or other legal instruments that allow sustainable use (SU) and/or limit any use and targets strict conservation (SC) Examples of legal instruments for SU other than management categories is in the take zones.
The project adopted in its elaboration the physical-environmental criteria discussed by the World Bank and the WWF, in order to identify eco-regions with mangroves. Seven eco-regions were identified in Brazil:
UNIT I: from Mouth of Rio Oiapoque to Mouth of Rio Araguari (AP)
UNIT II: from Mouth of Rio Araguari (AP) to Colares (PA)
UNIT III: from Colares (PA) to Parnaíba Delta (MA/PI)
UNIT IV: From Parnaíba Delta (MA/PI) to Rio Guajú (RN/PB)
UNIT V: Form Rio Guajú (RN/PB) to BA/ES boundary
UNIT VI: from BA/ES boundary to Cabo Frio (RJ)
UNIT VII: from Cabo Frio (RJ) to Barra do Sul (SC)
When the project was elaborated (2004/2005), there where 132 CUs: 89 CUs belonged to the Sustainable Use categories and 43 to the strict conservation ones. Nowadays, there are 162 CUs: 94 in SU category (58%), and 68 in SC category (42%).
Unit (# CUs) % SU %SC
I (3) 0% 100%
II (7) 72% 28%
III (21) 86% 14%
IV (16) 75% 25%
V (55) 62% 38%
VI (14) 57% 42%
VII (46) 37% 63%
It should be noticed that the project prompts and supports the creation and enlargement of several CUs of the SU category (i.e. RESEX - extractive reserves, in Amazon coastal area of Pará en Maranhão states). During the reporting period, the project supported the creation if three RESEX and the enlargement of one in Pará (October 2014), and is involved in the creation of other five RESEX and the enlargement of one in Pará and Maranhão. More details in indicator # 1 of the outcome # 2.
Finally, we mention that the present indicator takes into consideration the categories of the CUs as a whole. However, within each SU conservation unit, the project supports the elaboration of official management tools (such as the Management Agreements in Salgado Paraense, and te Management Plans in APA CIP and Mamanguape). Those tools establish the zoning of the CUs and the allowed use of each zone, thus SC percentage is higher than reported, due to the fact that parts of SU units are no-take zones (logically assimilated to strict conservation areas).

description.narrative: 4. % Management effectiveness (METT) of pilot mangrove PAs

comment.narrative:
METT applied during PDF B on a sample of pilot UCs:
Poor: 1%
Fair: 61%
Good: 27%
Excellent: 1%
70% Pilot UCs with a METT score of Good/Excellent

As mentioned in PIR 2014, there is an ongoing debate within the ICMBio on most adequate tools and processes for monitoring and evaluation of effectiveness of CUs and their performance in conserving biodiversity. In-progress processes are:
- Harmonization between METT and RAPPAM (the official tool of the Ministry of Environment). The purpose of the project is to use a tool whose values/results can be monitored in the future and compared.
- Development of an ICMBio system for M&E of effectiveness of CUs and management support to CUs managers in planning and decision making, leaded by the Directorate for Creation and Management of CUs – DIMAN/CGCAP.
In any case, the METT will be applied as planned, and it will be completed with inputs form other sources (e.g. RAPPAM; ongoing study on financial sustainability of CUs with mangroves, in the frame of output # 1.3, outcome # 1). So far, according to 2012 METT (applied in the frame of the MTR): poor 8%; fair 58%; good 38%; excellent 0%. However, it must be mentioned that some criteria of the METT format applied in in 2012 are different from those used in 2007, finalscore changed, thus the comparison with baseline METT is not linear.

description.narrative: 5. % of other pilot PAs testing 1 or more of financing strategies developed in the project

comment.narrative:
The study on financial sustainability of CUs with mangroves is under elaboration. The Brazilian Fund for Biodiversity (FUNBIO) is the partner for the elaboration of the study, in alliance with sector-specialized NGOs. Study includes training for CUs managers and civil servants and recommendations of specific financial tools in specific areas. It must be mentioned that FUNBIO is an implementing partner of the GEF MAR project, also executed by the ICMBio: a similar activity is expected in GEF MAR on financial sustainability of marine and coastal CUs. The project stimulated the dialogue and articulated with GEF MAR staff: the ongoing study represent phase # 1 (elaboration of strategy, definition of good practices, recommendations, training; advocacy at federal level) and it will be continued within the GEF MAR (implementation; advocacy and incidence; institutionalization).
On the other hand, during the reporting period, the project supports the Mosaic Lagamar in the negotiation of financial support though parliamentary amendments at state and municipal level, in order to capture a percentage of environmental compensations generated by the CUs that are part of the mosaic (the payment of environmental services and ICMS-E, among others). It is a recommendation of the Diagnostic on Normative Framework in Mangroves Areas, elaborated by the project in 2012: The project staff considers it as a concrete initiative on financial sustainability, and the evaluation of the experience will feed the ongoing study.

Nonetheless, we mention that the PAN (National Action Plan for Mangroves) was finalized and promulgated by the ICMBio: it gives substantial inputs to the Plan. The mentioned actors and stakeholders validated the PAN (Normative Instrument N° 1 published on January 29th 2015).

description.narrative: The enabling environment for a sub-system of mangrove ecosystem protected areas is in place, including policy, regulatory, and financial mechanisms
1. % of â€œMangroveâ€? States with a set of norms and guidelines agreed with and coordinated between federal, state and municipal agencies on the management of mangroves.

comment.narrative: 0 % of the States
At least 80% of the States

More than 50% of states where the project intervenes adopted the Normative Instruction 09072013 dealing with the crab transportation (4 states over 7; Piaui, Ceara, Maranhão and Pará). Furthermore, several initiatives are under implementation: a) the project works for the elaboration of guidelines on qualified management agreements for the mangroves areas (until September 2015, based on the ongoing experience in “Salgado Paraense” Pilot Area); b) the PAN-mangrove was published in January 2015; c) regulations for mangroves in the framework of the Management Plan of the APA CIP (under elaboration), as benchmark for future management plans in CUs with mangroves; d) constitution and functioning of the Technical Chamber for Water Resources within the council of the APA Barra do Rio Mamanguape (activation in May 2014; results expected in October 2015). Finally, several activities of the project contribute to the advocacy strategy for the discussion and modification of parts of the New Forest Code (Law nº 12.651, May 2012). As mentioned, the Law allows the increase of shrimp and salt production in mangrove areas.

description.narrative: 2. Existence of a core group of trained staff members (of IBAMA/ICMBIO, OEMAs and/or municipal agencies) capable of implementing and using those norms and regulations

comment.narrative: < 30% of States have core group of trained staff in key aspects of mangrove management By end of year one full staff competency skills specific for mangrove UC manager will have been defined and baseline and end targets determined

All OEMAs (BA, CE, MA, PA, PB, PI, PR, SP) involved, have a core group of staff-members trained in procedures of licensing & enforcement for mangrove conservation At least 1 more specialized staff in agency for mangrove management in each case

- Training on IN09072013 and the use of baskets for crabs transportation, implemented by the SEPAq (Secretary for the Development of Agriculture and Fishery of the state of Pará), which is a relevant partner of the project in “Salgado Paraense” pilot area. So far, 1.700 fishermen were trained (approx. 35% women) in 11 CUs, of whom approximately 100 are communitarian leaders and civil servants.
- Implementation and expansion of the “Protagonist Youth” training action; in 2015, the project elaborated and started modules for CUs managers, in order to train them and turn them into replication agents, and to expand the training activities with communitarian leaders at local level.
- Training activities on SocMon for CUs managers and technicians (an internationally applied methodology for social-environmental monitoring). In 2015, one training workshop was realized; 32 civil servants participated. In the second semester of 2015, more training activities will be realized.
- Training activities in Pará state are under implementation, in the frame of the elaboration of Management Agreement of nine RESEX. Activities involve and train civil servants at local level, especially those from municipalities and Pará public institutions. Number of trained people will be reported in next report.
- Training activities in “Delta do Parnaiba” pilot area started in June 2015, in order to elaborate the Crab Management Plan. In the frame of the Plan, 40 meetings (workshops and training activities) are designed for public sector personnel.
- In APA CIP and Lagamar Mosaic pilot area, more than 400 people participated to training activities and workshops in the frame of: a) elaboration of the APA CIP Management Plan (approximately 30% of participants are civil servants, mostly at municipal level); b) cartographic and thematic database management (more than 80% of participants are civil servants, especially CUs managers and personnel of environmental agencies at state level).

description.narrative: 3. # regulations tailored to mangroves in at least: UC management categories management plans guidelines financing mechanisms integrating water planning to mangroves fisheries management plans for mangrove UC

comment.narrative: 0 0 0 0 Measures for fisheries management are insufficient to provide sustainability

2 1 for each management category 4 1 resolution presented to CNRH linking classification of water bodies upstream from mangroves to needs of these ecosystems 1 resolution outlining rules and procedures for ecosystem-based, integrated fisheries resources management

UC management categories:
The project supports the development of the management agreements for 9 RESEX in Pará state. The outcomes of this process will support the elaboration of guidelines for management agreements at national level, specifically for CUs of sustainable use.
Management plans guidelines:
Considering that CUs with mangroves are mostly in a category for sustainable use, the project prioritizes guidelines for RESEX (Extractive Reserve) and APA (Environmental Protection Area).
- Management Plan of the APA CIP; the zoning considers the several existing instruments (such as Municipal Plans for Environments, Directors Plan, Management Plans of other Conservation Units inside the APA, Ecological Economic Zoning of the States for São Paulo and Paraná, among others).
- Participation to the deliberative / consultative councils and to the Technical Committees of the Conservation Units in pilot areas. Thematic calendars have been defined for each council (e.g. urban expansion, climatic change, zoning, traditional communities) as well as working groups, in order to better perform the duties of the councils.
- Elaboration and diffusion of the Guidelines for Managers and Counselors of the Councils of Federal Conservation Unites, elaborated by the CGSAM/DISAT.
Financing mechanisms:
- Study on financial mechanism in CUs with mangroves, in order to elaborate a national strategy. The execution of the diagnostic and strategy is responsibility of FUNBIO. The project already linked this action to the GEF MAR project: implementation/test, training activities, and a continuum strategy on financial sustainability in coastal and marine CUs will be maintained in the GEF MAR.
- Mosaic Lagamar (APA CIP Pilot Area) in the negotiation of the financial support though parliamentary amendments at state and municipal level, in order to capture a percentage of environmental compensations generated by the CUs that are part of the mosaic.
Integrating water planning to mangroves:
- Specific actions and programmes for the management of water resources have been designed and officially approved within the PAN Mangrove.
- A Technical Chamber for Water Resources has been activated within the Management Council of the Mamanguape APA and AIRE. The project is developing the diagnosis of water resources and a monitoring protocol on water quality. The Chamber will develop and promote research, data sharing mechanisms and mitigation actions through competent bodies.
- The management plan for the APA CIP pilot area is proposing programmes and regulations on water resources quality, with emphasis on the mangroves conservation.
Fisheries management plans for mangrove UC:
- Crab Management Plan for the Delta do Parnaiba Pilot Area (APA and RESEX), with FADESP and Goeldi Museum is. The participatory process will finish in December..
- Management agreements for 9 RESEX in Pará state: fishery activities are the main issue of the management agreements.
- Management of a critical situation in October/December 2014 in APA CIP, and participated to the modification of an excessively restrictive measure of the State of São Paulo on fishery activities of some species. The project staff collected data and elaborated a technical report that led to the modification of the Decree at state level, the re-allowance of supervised fishery activities, and the designation of APA CIP as responsible for census and authorization of fishermen for those species (linked to stock monitoring activities).

description.narrative: 4. Composition/source of financing in the project intervention areas that will develop new financing strategies

comment.narrative: UC funding comes from Federal and State budgets with an average funding gap of 50% in mangrove UCs
Tested mechanisms increase PA funding 30% in the two pilot intervention areas (Bahia and SP)

The action is under implementation with FUNBIO, as mentioned in other sections. According to monitoring plan, this indicator will be reported at the end of the project, as part of the outcome of the METT.

description.narrative: 5. Existence of a national mangroves plan in Brazilâ€™s Wetland Plan

comment.narrative: No plan . Activities for conserving mangroves are ad hoc and un-coordinated with on-going plans and programmes
Mangrove Plan agreed and legally formalized as part of Wetlands and contributes to target of national PA Plan

As mentioned, the National Plan will be developed by the end of the project. Eventually, the project staff participates to the meetings of the National Commission for Humid Zones, where advocacy activities already started in order to gain incidence in the wetland plan (e.g. the application of the APA CIP to Ramsar site has been accepted and it is now supported by the Commission and the Ministry of Environment).

description.narrative: Replicable models are in place for the management of mangrove resources in SNUC sustainable-use protected areas.

1. Degree of ecosystem management of fisheries resources in Para
# hectares under integrated fisheries resource plan
# no-take areas in the 3 pilot UCs

comment.narrative:
0 ha under fisheries resource plan that limit practices and catches.
0 no-take areas agreed

70,000 ha under ecosystem-based, integrated fisheries resource plan.
3 no-take zones agreed

# hectares under integrated fisheries resource plan: Approximately 300.000 ha. As mentioned in PIR 2014, the following CUs participates to the development of the Management Agreements: Soure (27.464 ha); São João da Ponta (3.203 ha); Mãe Grande de Curuça (37.062 ha); Maracanã (30.019 ha); Chocoaré- Mato Grosso (2.785 ha); Tracuateua (27.153ha); Caeté-Taperaçu (42.068 ha); Araí-Peroba: (50.555 ha); Gurupi- Piriá (74.081 ha).Furthermore, three new CUs (RESEX category) were created in October 2014 in Pará state, with the support of the project: Cuinarana (11.037ha); Mocapajuba (26.465ha); Mestre Lucindo (21.029ha). The project already realized actions with the aim to include those new CUs in ARPA (Programme for Protected Areas in Amazon), in order to guarantee the consolidation of those CUs beyond project lifespan. The project is also supporting the creation and enlargement of CUs in Pará, and Maranhão. It must be mentioned that this action created the most large continuous protected area of mangroves in the world (a non-interrupted coastal area from Pará to Maranhão), as reported in several media (See articles and releases in Communicating Impact section). # no-take areas in the 3 pilot UCs: The projects projection is to define and approve no-take zones in at least 7 CUs in Pará state. No-take areas have been identified in the management agreements of the RESEXs. Communities are elaborating rules about the exploitation of natural resources. By now, the project is supporting the development of qualified management agreements for the RESEXs in the Salgado Paraense. Although Management Agreements are tools for each CU, it must be noticed that those are the firsts that embrace an ecosystem-based approach and that define the management of the whole area (nine RESEX), including common zoning and regulations.

comment.narrative:
60% mortality in uÃ§a crab

No resource management plans exist for Uca crabs in sustainable use UC

25% decrease in mortality and harvesting at levels established in resource plan
20% decrease in capture of uÃ§Ã¡ crab and income remains same or higher

In the areas where the baskets have been tested according to the IN 09072013, the mortality rate is lower than 25%, actually achieving less than 5%, according to collected data in RESEX Sao Joao da Ponta. The IN is already adopted in four states (North / North-East); the project started an action to evaluate the IN effectiveness, in order to adapt the regulation to local contexts, along with the ICMBio/DISAT, the UNESCO and the NGO Conservation International.

description.narrative: 3. Development and marketing of new Mangrove products

comment.narrative:
At present, most local communities and populations lack the capacity to produce and market potential new products from mangrove areas
18 families involved in sustainable economic alternatives to uÃ§Ã¡ capture

100 potential local small entrepreneurs trained in the preparation of a business plan
100 families in the pilot UCs involved in sustainable alternatives including women and youth

According to Substantial Revision (January 2014), the focus of the project moved from market access of mangroves products to market promotion and income generation through land planning and management tools. Management agreements in Salgado Paraense pilot area, and the Crab Management Plan in Delta do Parnaiba pilot area are the most relevant actions of the project in order to achieve the outcome. Several data show that developed technologies and tolls (e.g. the normative on crab transportation, zoning and stock monitoring) had relevant impact on income of vulnerable and poor coastal communities: e.g. average weekly revenues for fishery activities at household level for families that adopted the crab transportation technology rise from R$ 130,4 to R$ 198,2, representing 24% increment.

description.narrative: 4. Number of UC and cluster management councils reaching agreement on harvesting levels and enforcement in Pilot areas

comment.narrative: At least 20 CUs applied and/or are elaborating regulations and rules: Management agreements in Salgado Paraense pilot area, and the Crab Management Plan in Delta do Parnaiba pilot area are under elaboration; the Working Group on Fishery of the APA CIP council reached agreements that led to the stock monitoring and fishermen census, and norms are under elaboration within the Management Plan.

description.narrative:
Conservation of mangroves is improved by piloting the alignment of UC management with
sectors and spatial planning

1. # of water management instruments agreed upon by the Mamanguape waterbasin committee that take into
account the water quantity and quality for mangroves

comment.narrative: 0 of 6

So far, two management instruments were defined: a) the activation of the Technical Chamber for Water Resources within the Management Council of the “Barra do Rio Mamanguape” APA and AIRE; b) a monitoring protocol on water quality.
The two management tools have been defined and approved by the APA and ARIE councils. Eventually, a diagnostic of water resources is under implementation through an external consultancy, it is: a) a baseline for the monitoring protocol; b) a database and diagnostic for the elaboration of proposals and programmes by the Chamber. The Chamber will develop and promote research, data sharing mechanisms and mitigation actions.
It must be noticed that:
1) There is not a unique water-basin committee; the two water basin committees (Upper and Lower) participate of the Chamber;
2) SUDEMA (authority for environment in the state of Parnaiba) already monitors some parameters. The defined protocol complements those parameters and communicate with SUDEMA database. The Aquatic Mammals Foundation (FMA) also shared relevant data on flora and fauna. The two stakeholders participate to the councils and to the Chamber.
3) The monitoring protocol will be applied by students of the Federal University of Parnaiba. The university participates to the council and to the chamber; the in-the-field work of the students is in the frame of the Inter-institutional Collaboration Agreement between the APA and the university: it is costless for the ICMBio and it will be applied during next years (continuity; technical and financial sustainability).
4) Private sector representatives participate to the councils and to the chamber. Most relevant are the association of shrimp producers and the union of sugar cane and alcohol producers. Indigenous communities are also represented (communitarian leaders), along with FUNAI (National Fund for Indigenous People).
The project expect the approval of at least one more management tolls. The Chamber is discussing the elaboration of technical proposals, with the aim to turn them into management instruments for water resources: a) Action Plan with contingency measures based on agreed alarm-level monitored indicators; Terms for Conduct Adjustments (TCA); new inter-institutional collaboration agreements.

description.narrative:
2. Degree that mangrove conservation is incorporated in Zoning of the ReentrÃ¢ncias Maranhenses APA
Zoning restriction on main sectors reflected in UC plan
# municipalities agreed on APA zoning
% of the key actors in APA have signed a formal document of adherence to zoning regulations

comment.narrative:
Initial zoning for agro-ecological activities, shrimp farming, and indicators starting for deforestation but reflected in PA-planning and management.
1 municipality in the APA has a development plan that considers mangrove needs zoning.
0% of the key actors in APA have signed a formal document of adherence to zoning regulations

UC management plan reflects zoning and limits of all main economic activities
16 municipalities (200,000 ha.) in the APA have agreed on the zoning.
50% of the key actors in the APA sign formal document of adherence to zoning regulations.

Two main outputs contribute to the outcome and this specific indicator:
1. The APA CIP management Plan. So far, 42 meetings/workshops have been done, involving almost 700 people. Six municipalities have part of their territories inside the APA CIP limits, representatives participate to workshops and to the elaboration process.
Mangrove conservation has been included in Management Plan as a cross-cutting issue in all thematic and geographic components of the Plan, and a specific zone has been created (Mangrove Conservation Zone). Three geographic sectors have been identified. Thematic clusters have been defined: traditional communities; water resources; urban expansion; climate changes; fishery and aquaculture; agriculture and farming; tourism; non-fishery natural resources.
Zoning was concluded and it will be presented between the 25 of June and the 15 of July, along with specific regulations and restrictions for each sector. Specific mangrove protection area have been mapped and included in the Plan. The Plan is elaborated with a broad participation of social stakeholders, indigenous and traditional communities, organized civil society (e.g. universities; NGOs and foundations), public authorities at municipal, state and federal level. So far, municipalities participates to the process.
2. The Action Plan of the Lagamar Mosaic was elaborated and it is now under revision and validation. The project promoted and supported the creation of the management mechanism in the Mosaic. The Mosaic is composed by 54 CUs with different jurisdictions. The project supported the Mosaic in the elaboration of a single cartographic and bibliographic database, along with the “Atlantic Forest and Climate Changes” Project of the Ministry of Environment, supported by the German Cooperation (GIZ and KfW), with which the project maintains synergies.

description.narrative: Mangrove-related outreach, dissemination and adaptive management is increased.
1. Awareness among private and public stakeholders on the management of mangrove UCs and the ecosystem services they provide.

comment.narrative: TBD by survey in first six months.
Increased by at least 30% compared to baseline survey

The indicator will be reported by the end of the project, after the application of a random-sample survey about people perception on mangroves.
1. Awareness and dissemination campaigns have been organized and executed, especially in the frame of the “Protagonist Youth” initiative, that already mobilized more than 500 people at community level in Pará state, 30% of which are women.
2. Communication over ecosystem services will be realized as part of the dissemination and knowledge sharing of the outcomes of the FUNBIO ongoing study on financial sustainability of CUs with mangroves.
3. The international seminar for the participatory monitoring of biodiversity was a relevant forum where the project participated and communicated mangrove status and project outputs and outcomes. It was realized in September 2014 in Manaus, with the participation of more than 250 people.
4. The project along with the Coordination for Production (ICMBio/DISAT/COPROD) is executing the last phase of a systematization process (started in 2014), focused on successful experiences of economic, social and cultural inclusion in Sustainable Use marine and coastal CUs. Nine experiences were systematized; the project is now finalizing las in-the-field missions, validating the information, editing the texts.
5. A video was realized by the Coordination for Environmental Education (ICMBio/DISAT/COEDU), with the participation of the project: “Extrativist Citizens” (which means people of the RESEXs).
6. Massive communication campaign was realized during last months of 2014 (articles on blogs, national and stat newspapers and magazines, interviews in national and local televisions). We enjoyed a positive visibility conjuncture, thanks to the creation of three new RESEX with mangroves in the Para State, that constitute the largest continuous protected mangrove area in the world. The issue was also published in the official blog of the President Dilma Roussef (more data in Communication section).

description.narrative: 2. Frequency and quality of monitoring of mangrove land cover

comment.narrative: Uncoordinated individual state M&E programs
M&E programs coordinated and linked to national system

1. Data on extension of cover vegetation of mangroves in Brazil and in Pilot Areas are under elaboration with CSR-IBAMA (see information reported for indicator # 2 of the Objective). CSR monitors the mangrove coverage every year.
2. The Programme for Monitoring of Biodiversity is under development, with the intent of harmonizing all monitoring tools and protocols on mangroves (e.g. fishery resources stock monitoring; threatened species; PAN Mangrove; participatory monitoring). The process is executed through external consultancy and leaded by the Coordination for Monitoring for Biodiversity (ICMBio/DIBIO/COMOB).

description.narrative: 3. Number of instances in which adaptive management takes place taking into account M&E results

comment.narrative: As mentioned in PIR 2014, internal M&E task has been enhanced since 2013: data on efficiency, financial and technical resources, processes and effectiveness over indicators achievements are monthly elaborated and reported to project coordination, and supports strategy reviews, implementation of activities, and decision making. The M&E functions, along with the adoption of operative tools, allowed the optimization of resources and a more result-oriented approach (i.e. the SIMA – System for Information Management, Monitoring and Evaluation, which will be used in other ICMBio projects).

description.narrative: 4. Number of replications of the Project pilots Brazilâ€™s in other mangrove PA

comment.narrative: The indicator will be reported at the end of the project, as part of the replication strategy. So far, it shall be mentioned that: a) management agreement will be replicated by the ICMBIo in at least the three new CUs in the state of Pará; they share the Pará mangrove-amazonian coast and the natural resources of the nine RESEX already involved in the elaboration process; b) the “Protagonist Youth” initiative is adopted by the ICMBio and training modules for CUs managers are under execution in order to turn managers into replication agents; c) the technology for crab transportation has been adopted in four states and its evaluation and replication is supported by the ICMBio.

title.narrative: 00048524_PIMS 3665 BRA09G31 Transformacao de Mercado EE PRODOC PORT

description.narrative: BRA/09/G31 - Energy Efficiency in Buildings
independent political entity
Energy - power generation
1. EE offer fully functional in private and public building sector. 2. EE Product and Service providers trained. 3. Number of public projects under the Public Buildings Initiative (PBI) approach.

comment.narrative: 1. Limited capacity in term of EE offer from local market players. 2. Limited capacity of EE product and service providers. 3. No tender process for public buildings.

1. EE market capacity building strategy in place. 2. Up to 1,400 EE product/service providers trained (ESCOs, equipment providers, building owners/ managers/associations, engineering associaciations, education institutions, universities, etc) by the end of the project. 3. Initiatives on Public Buildings undertaken.

1. Capacity Development Plan Revised and two new Technical Cooperation Agreements stablished in the private sector with Green Building Council and ABESCO (National ESCO Association) to help implement capacity development activities and disseminate EE business model. A company was hired to elaborate 2 practical guides (Building Certification/Labelling and Energy audits) and 8 videos on PBE Edifica (National Building Labelling Program) that will be used in trainings and dissemination activities in the public and private sectors. Total of 400 people trained on EE financing and PBE Edifica. 2. 1 x 8hs training (50 participants) for banks and ESCOs on evaluation of EE projects; 11 x 4hs workshop ( 209 participants) on PBE/Edifica - Brazilian Building Labelling Program- for private (3 workshops) and public (8 workshops) sectors . 5 x 20 hs training (16 hs presential + 4hs distance learning) on PBE Edifica (146 participants). 3. The PBI approach should be considered more as a partnership with public agents working on energy efficiency than an independent initiative within the project. In order to achieve a higher number of procurement process of EE projects in the public sector and indicate best ways to implement EE projects, a public call was launched to gather energy consumption data from public office buildings. 320 buildings data were gathered and this information is being analyzed and structured in a benchmarking of energy consumption, which will define a consumption indicators for public buildings (KWh/m2). 20 buildings will be selected for energy audits and at least five buildings will be assisted (juridically and technically) to procure and implement energy efficiency projects.

description.narrative: To foster EE investments in private and public buildings in Brazil.
1. Increase in the number and in annual revenues of EE project developers

comment.narrative: Very few buildings owners/operators have incorporated EE measures
Increase in investment in EE for building public and private sectors by USD93 million

The Project is intensively informing and training service providers and project developers about the normative instruction (IN 02) and PBE Edifica. The Planning Ministry (MPOG) has launched an ordinance in Feb 2015 that stablishes best practices and monitoring indicators for energy use in public buildings. MPOG is being technically assisted by the Project. In 2015 Brazil was considered to enter recession, the prices of energy rose 60% and energy efficiency came back to the deabte, however, the interest rates and the availability of financial resources decreased, there is a potential for speeding and enhancing the number of EE projects, but it unclear if EE investments will peak.

description.narrative: 2. Rate of public and private building owners/operators reported to use ESCOs services to improve their energy consumption (at least 80%)

comment.narrative: Govt. buildings operation do not specify minimum EE performance values
Local banking system provide financing in 70% of EE projects

There is a huge complexity to measure the utilization of EE services for the total building stock, once only in the federal sphere there are 28.000 buildings. However, through a 5 month public call, the Project has managed to identify energy consumption detailed data from 320 public buildings office to define the baseline of consumption and specify performance values.

description.narrative: 3. Number of FI offering energy savings guarantee services to other sources

comment.narrative: Professionals and developers do not understand basic EE principles
At least 10 FIs and value (at least $ 123M in total) of financed EE investment enabled by the Project, including by local FIs

Two regional Banks (Desenvolve São Paulo and AgeRio - Estate Foment Agency of Rio de Janeiro) have been assessed and aproved by IDB to use the EEGM. BNDES is part of the Consultive Committee and has been very active. The Project is trying to enhance cooperation with National Bank Associations and Federations (ABBC and FEBRABAN) and the reestructuring of PROESCO might increase the number and amount of financed projects.

description.narrative: 4. Number of new EE implemented projects using the EEGM or other similar mechanism due to the Project

comment.narrative: Financing institutions are not aware on how they can support the development of EE market
At least 250 projects implemented, resulting in direct CO2 emission reduction of 2 MT CO2 and post-project and indirect 16 MT CO2.

Since last PIR 1 more letter was issued by EEGM to APS Engenharia (total of 4 letters). EEGM has the total of 4 closed projects and there is a current pipeline of 7 more, 2 of which are in final negotiations. The four closed totaled US$1.6M, leveraging US$ 10 million. It is important to note that the goal of 250 projects considered some assumptions that did not occur (total revolving of resources in year 3 and small ize of projects), therefore the resources available in EEGM and the demonstrative projects implemented by component 2 shall achieve 35 to 40 projetcs nationally in the best scenario.

description.narrative: Enhanced EE investments through CB in EE in private & public buildings
5. EE offer fully functional in private and public building sector

comment.narrative: Limited capacity in term of EE offer from local market players
EE building market capacity building in progress by Yr 1; · Efficiency Improvement in Brazil reinforced by Yr 5

Capacity Development Plan Revised and two new Technical Cooperation Agreements stablished in the private sector with Green Building Council and ABESCO (National ESCO Association) to help implement capacity development activities and disseminate EE business model. A company was hired to elaborate 2 practical guides (Building Certification/Labelling and Energy audits) and 8 videos on PBE Edifica (National Building Labelling Program) that will be used in trainings and dissemination activities in the public and private sectors. Total of 400 people trained on EE financing and PBE Edifica.

description.narrative: 6. EE Product and Service providers trained

comment.narrative: Limited capacity of EE product and service providers
Up to 1,400 EE product/service providers trained (ESCOs, equipment providers, building owners/ managers/associations, engineering associaciations, education institutions, universities, etc).

1 x 8hs training (50 participants) for banks and ESCOs on evaluation of EE projects; 11 x 4hs workshop ( 209 participants) on PBE/Edifica - Brazilian Building Labelling Program- for private (3 workshops) and public (8 workshops) sectors . 5 x 20 hs training (16 hs presential + 4hs distance learning) on PBE Edifica (146 participants).

description.narrative: 7. Increased awareness and interest by market players in implementing EE measures

comment.narrative: Limited awareness activities conducted by the Authorities on the benefits of EE

Up to 5,000 people from public and private building sector trained; . 2,000 stakeholders reached with project publications and; . 1,000 unique visitors to project website six months after site is launched.

Average of 12.000 accesses monthly in Projeteee (http://projeteee.ufsc.br) a reference online plataform developed to support the design of new efficient buildings. Dissemination of lessons learnt in the labelling of MMA buliding by distribution of 3.000 copies of the publication "Practical Guide for energy efficiency - the experience of project labelling from MMA( Ministry of Environment)". The Project created a visual identity and developed a series of dissemination materials ( folders, banners, logo, ecobags, pencards). The Project's website is active and hosted in MMA's webpage under Climate/Energy: http://mma.gov.br/clima/energia/edif%C3%ADcios

description.narrative: Access to EE services and commercial financing for public sector buildings enhanced with a PBI
8. PBI Program for Public Buildings operational by end of project, including EE tender processes alternatives

comment.narrative: The current purchasing mechanism for public sector is lowest cost only
Model for PBI designed by end of first year; · Public sector EE Promotion plan drafted and submitted to the Gov. for adoption by the end of Yr 2.

Despite of PBI not being structured as described in PRODOC, the Project is partnering with the most important initiatives in the public sector to promote energy efficiency such as: Programa Esplanada Sustentável (PES), Programa A3P (Environmental Agenda in the Public Administration) with the Secretariats of Information Technology and Logistics (SLTI) and Federal Budget (SOF), both from the Planning Ministry and PROCEL (Brazilian Energy Conservation Program) to improve and enhance the results and impacts of existing initiatives to promote energy efficiency. Conclusion of the direct contract of CBCS (Brazilian Council for Sustainable Construction) to implement a benchmarking of energy consumption in public buildings (offices) aiming to define indicators and implement 20 energy audits in public buildings in order to identify best cases to demonstrate procedures for procurement of EE projets. The project is providing technical assistance for the consolidation of the Normative Instruction IN02 SLTI and the Ordinance 23 (both elaborated by the Planning ministry) and aimed at defining energy efficiency standards and monitoring procedures for public buildings.

description.narrative: 9. Number of public projects undertaken by ESCOS under the PBI approach.

comment.narrative: No tender process for public buildings under performance contract
Average of 15 RFPs/year based on PBI approach.

The PBI aproach should be considered more as a partnership with public agents working on energy effficency than an independent initiative within the project and the number of 15 RFPs anually based on PBI might be infeasible to accomplish. In order to achieve a higher number of procurement proccess of EE projetcs in the public sector and indicate best ways to implement EE projects, a public call was launched to gather energy consumption data from public office buildings. Given the difficulty to recieve data it was extended to 5 months 320 buildings data were gathered. This information will be analysed and structured in a benchmarking of energy consumption, which will define a consumption indicators for public buildings (KWh/m2). 20 buildings will be selected for energy audits and at least five buildings will be assisted (juridically and technically) to procure and implement energy effciency projetcs.

description.narrative: 10. ESCOs develop and implement pilot projects on public sector buildings

comment.narrative: Limited experience in ESCO projects in public buildings
Five pilot projects for public building sector by the end of Yr 3.

Executive projects for the retrofit of MMA ready. The Retrofit project has recieved Procel Label, which is issued to most efficient projects (triple A - lighting, envelope, air conditioning). This was the first federal building in Brasilia to have PROCEL label and it broke the paradigm that the building envelope could not be A at the Esplanada. In order to implement the EE measures the eletric project and digital network projects are being procured. Given the budget restrictions in the whole public sector in 2015, MMA will have to search for alternative sources to implement measures and is partnering with ANEEL (National Electric Energy Agency) and local utilities to identify resources available for implementation.

description.narrative: Interest enhanced in the replacement of energy-inefficient CFC-using chillers

The indicators of component 3 have chaged substantially once this outcome was turned into a new Project BRA12/G77. The chillers inventory showed that there are very few chillers operating with CFC in Brazil and that there are aprox. 130.000 equipments in operation with HCFC-22. Therefore, HCFC was included in the spectrum of chillers approached by this outcome. Outcome1 (BRA12/G77): National Inventory of CFC and HCFC developed. Indicator: Number of CFC chillers in Brazil assessed.

Up to 40 CFC-based chillers replacement demonstration projects using MLF co-financing implemented by the end of Yr 2.

BRA/08/G32: BRAZIL - ESTABLISHMENT OF PCB MANAGEMENT AND DISPOSAL PROGRAM

title.narrative: BRA/08/G32 Establishment of PCB Management and Disposal Program

description.narrative: BRA/08/G32 - BRAZIL ESTABLISHMENT OF PCB MANAGEMENT AND DISPOSAL PROGRAM
independent political entity

The main development objective of the project is to enhance the capacity to manage and dispose of PCB waste in a sustainable manner and by extension to minimize risk of PCB exposure to the population and the environment.
1. Number of reviewed and approved standards and rules for PCB management

comment.narrative: 1. Incomplete and fractured legislation, guidance and PCB programs
1.1 Complete, actualized and eficient standards, guidelines and rules for PCB management.

Energy - power generation
To create the conditions for sugar mills to increase the export of electricity generated by sugar cane trash and bagasse to the grid.
Trash system implemented and operating

comment.narrative: No mills or distilleries are using the trash produced by the green harvesting

Trash system successfully demonstrated in one mill by end of year 3
Trash system successfully operating in 3 mills by end of project

The project has not initiated its activities with GEF resources yet. However, during the assessment of the situation it has been verified that the work on the first mill with co-financing from MCTI has been satisfactorily undertaken at Alta Mogiana Mill. A visit was made in order to formalize a cooperation agreement between CTBE and the mill through the project duration. Besides, in order to update the trash system baseline, it was started an evaluation of the state of art at the mill. Additionally, Usina da Pedra Mill and Raízen Group demonstrated interest in participating of the project. All the three sent representatives to the Inception Workshop, and their participation with explanation of the activities being conducted in terms of trash experiments confirmed their willingness to proceed investing to increase electricity generation with trash, as far as technology and barriers can be properly addressed.

description.narrative: CATALYZING THE CONTRIBUTION OF INDIGENOUS LANDS TO THE CONSERVATION OF BRAZIL’S FOREST ECOSYSTEMS
lake
Environment - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1. No standards for environmental management of ILs. 2. Very limited resources used for environmental management of ILs (1 or 2 pilot experiences throughout the country). 3. No capacity for implementation of norms and regulations for ethno-management and ethno-zoning in ILs (<20% of MMA staff and <15% of FUNAI with some knowledge of BD conservation and use in ILs).

1. Regular meetings of SC with PNGATI Conferences taking place. 2. An Intergrated Plan for implementation of PNGATI for PPA 2016-2019 prepared for financing of land and environmental management plans in ILs. 3. Capacity building initiatives undertaken in order to train IPs and staff in MMA, IBAMA, ICMBio, FUNAI, among others, in order to implement and follow specific norms and regulations for ethno-management and ethno-zoning in ILs.

description.narrative: A ground-tested and officially recognized strategy for environmental management in Indigenous Lands (IL) by Indigenous Peoples (IP) is adopted in Brazil for the effective conservation and sustainable use of forest biodiversity

1. Increase in the area (ha.) of representative forest ecosystems of Brazil under conservation through the recognized environmental goals of ILs that by the end of the project are:
(i) incorporated into a network of ethno-management practices for conservation of different forest ecosystems in Brazil; ILs (ha) in network with recognized BD goals
(ii) identified as contributing to long term targets of PNAP and part of IL Environmental Management Plan with specific strategies for implementation; ILs (ha) in long term plans

comment.narrative: 1. Currently ILs in different forest biomes provide conservation to forest biodiversity but the contribution to national conservation plans and targets is not measured nor are the IPs management practices readily translated into terms that can be recognized and funded through resources available for biodiversity conservation. The potential for contribution to Brazilâ€™ conservation goals is thus not fully recognized.

The PNGATI Steering Committee, installed on Oct. 30, 2013, has since met several times. During the 2nd CG PNGATI Ordinary Meeting, on 03/25 - 26/2014, two Technical Councils were created: one to organize the PNGATI National Conference and the other to create the Integrated Plan for PNGATI implementation (PIPNGATI). The latter promoted a workshop on 11/20 - 21/2014 to create a logical framework for implementation of the Policy. This framework will be used by the different ministries to orient the federal government´s Pluriannual Plan for 2016-2019, currently being constructed by the Ministry of Planning and Budget. And during the 4th Ordinary Meeting (12/02-21/03/2014), the CG PNGATI discussed the planning framework proposal and defined a timeline for ordinary meetings in 2015.

description.narrative: Cerrrado/P.

comment.narrative: According to the Permanent Interministerial Working Group PPCerrado´s 2nd Phase Report (2014-2015), the 95 Indigenous Lands in the Cerrado Biome continue to show very low rates of deforestation, on the order of 4% of their total area (slightly more than 90,000 km2). This compares very favorably with the rate for conservation areas (22%) and agricultural settlements (40%) and clearly demonstrates the effectivity of ILs in conserving biodiversity of the Cerrado, Brazil´s second largest biome.

comment.narrative: Through partnership with TNC, an alternative instrument to measure management effectiveness in ILs was created. This instrument was presented and improved in a workshop held in October 2014, at Funai in Brasília. The improved version was applied in Oiapoque ILs, with very positive results, including the perception of its usefulness by the village leaders involved in its application.

description.narrative:
4. Increase in IP capacities for leading and up-scaling environmental management actions for conserving representative forest ecosystems in Brazil
IOs, with institutional &technical capacities to execute & monitor IL National Plans & projects
Indigenous initiatives/centres for training in environmental management for BD conservation & sustainable use of natural resources

comment.narrative:
Today COIAB, FOIRN and CIR have institutional capacity for the execution of ethno-management and ethno-zoning plans. None has the capacity to execute a national plan of environmental management.
A Centre for Indigenous training exists in the Amazon CAFI and in 2006 trained 15 IPs in environmental management but this does not include standards and practices for ethno-zoning for BD conservation. Other regions do not have Centres or trained IPs

All IO of the 5 regional networks have strengthened capacities* for environmental management and to execute & monitor IL National Plans & projects.
20 IP in each of the biomes have skill required for ethno-environmental management

The itinerant training program Mosarambihara (Seeders) for the Guarani-Kaiowá of 3 reference areas in Mato Grosso do Sul, held its first course module in December 2014. The indigenous organization ASCURI has been hired by means of a Letter of Agreement to carry out the remaining modules and register the course in video.
The proposed course in Agroecology for the Terena with the Universidade Estadual do Mato Grosso do Sul (UEMS), Glória de Dourados campus, has been shifted from a techical degree to a full undergraduate degree. University personnel and indigenous representatives will meet with the Ministry of Education in Brasília on July 1, 2015, for further discussion as to funding mechanisms for this proposal.
Through an agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN), indigenous organizations in project reference areas presented proposals to a small grants program funded by the project, with 37 proposals approved (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=e236a7b66e&e=4a987eb951)

description.narrative: Mechanisms and tools have been developed that enable Brazilâ€™s ILs to be recognized and strengthened as effective areas for conserving forest biodiversity, natural resources and the environmental services
5.Existence of recognized environmental management standards and targets in Indigenous Lands

comment.narrative:
A National Protected Areas Plan (PNAP) exists to guide the establishment of a comprehensive system of protected areas including contributions from ILs s but no specific targets, standards or practices for these are defined.
In Sept 2008, a working group (GTI) was established to elaborate a proposal of National Policy for Environmental Management in IL

A National Conservation Plan for Indigenous Lands that contains targets for conservation of representative forest ecosystems through environmental management * exists and is harmonized and integrated with the NPAP and adapted to the environmental and social needs of ILs
[*this Plan would be aligned with and form part of a National Policy on Environmental Management of IL (PNGATI)]

The PNGATI Steering Committee, installed on Oct. 30, 2013, has since met several times. During the 2nd CG PNGATI Ordinary Meeting, on 03/25 - 26/2014, two Technical Councils were created: one to organize the PNGATI National Conference and the other to create the Integrated Plan for PNGATI implementation (PIIPNGATI). The latter promoted a workshop on 11/20 - 21/2014 to create a logical framework for implementation of the Policy. This framework will be used by the different ministries to orient the federal government´s Pluriannual Plan for 2016-2019, currently being constructed by the Ministry of Planning and Budget. And during the 4th Ordinary Meeting (12/02-21/03/2014), the CG PNGATI discussed the planning framework proposal and defined a timeline for ordinary meetings in 2015.

description.narrative: 6. Resources from existing biodiversity conservation sources used to achieve basic operating standards for environmental management in ILs

comment.narrative:
ILs currently do not receive funding for environmental management activities from public funding sources for biodiversity conservation.
Isolated support from NGOs to undertake environmental management and/or territorial surveillance activities in the ILs of Oiapoque, AmapÃ¡ and KayapÃ³

At least 5 of the Reference ILs will receive at least 50% of the costs of basic operations* from new funding mechanisms that include resources currently only available for biodiversity conservation in PA. environmental services compensation
[*The project will work to determine costs of meeting basic operational standards and will test different funding mechanisms.]

The project assisted in the establishment of a new technical cooperation project (BRA/13/019) between Funai and UNDP, signed in December 2013, to help implement PNGATI and apply resources from the Fundo Clima/MMA-Ministério do Meio Ambiente, The project assisted in drafting the public call for proposal for ethnomanagement plans (PGTAs) in the Caatinga and Cerrado biomes (R$ 2.8 million), launched in August 2014. O f the 15 proposals selected, 4 are project reference areas, and were written with the help of project consultants. Through a Letter of Agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN) the project is assisting in the initial training of the organizations carrying out the proposals.
The project assisted Funai and MMA in drafting the Fundo Amazonia/BNDES call for PGTA proposals - R$ 70 million (published in 08 May 2014) and helped the Andirá-Marau IL, a reference area, to prepare its proposal, in partnership with the Centro de Trabalho Indigenista (CTI). The proposal was approved, along with a proposal by CPI/Acre, which will benefit Mamoadate IL, another reference area.
Project partner TNC also approved a project with the Fundo Amazônia, in an earlier call for projects, for implementation of ethnomanagement plans in the reference areas where it is currently working (Amapá and Pará states) (R$ 15 million).

description.narrative: 7. Staff competencies and skills in MMA, IBAMA, ICMBio, FUNAI, OEMAs and/or municipal agencies) aligned to implement and follow specific norms and regulations for ethno-management and ethno-zoning in ILs.

The PNGATI training course held at Acadebio (Academia Nacional da Biodiversidade) for the Mata Atlantica Biome, a joint effort of Funai, MMA/ICMBio and the project held the last of its 5 modules in November, 2014.
The training course in PNGATI for the Northeast region, MG and ES, with 5 itinerant modules, 4 of which were in or nearby project reference areas (with visits, in the latter cases), held its last module in May 2015, with an optional visit to the Cavernas de Peruaçu National Park, arranged by an ICMBio employee who participated in the course.
A similar training course for the Cerrado biome held its first module in Brasília, in June 2015, with a MMA employee participating.
·  <20% of MMA/SBF trained on ethno-management and ethno-zoning plans for Ils
·  At least 20% increase in the number of MMA and FUNAI staff trained to implement and use such norms
See above

description.narrative: See above

comment.narrative: ·  <15% of FUNAI has core groups of staff trained on environmental management and sustainable use activities in IL
·  At least 1 staff member in the OEMAs of the states of SC, MS, BA, PE, AM, PA, AC and RO trained to monitor these norms and regulations
See above
·  OEMAs do not have staff trained on environmental activities in Ils
·  IBAMA and ICMBio

A limited number of OEMA staff have participated in the PNGATI courses. The PNGATI Cerrado course, organized and funded by Funai, held its first module in June, 2015, has among its participantes an employee of Naturatins, the environmental agency for the state of Tocantins.
·  IBAMA and ICMBio
·  Competency profiles for MMA/SF and FUNAI have been adjusted to include IL/IP and biodiversity conservation respectively

ICMBio employees participated in the PNGATI training courses, one of which took place at the ICMBio ´s Academia Nacional da Biodiversidade (Acadebio). Three ICMBio employees participated in the Northeast, Minas Gerais e Espirito Santo PNGATI training course. Participation in the PNGATI courses has contributed to change in the paradigms held by ICMBio employees. As cited previously, ICMBio employees in the courses have begun to regard indigenous peoples as partners in conservation, especially important in cases of overlap between ILs and conservation areas. This was clearly stated in a letter addressed to the incoming president of ICMBio at the end of May 2015, and signed by more than 300 employees, the greater portion of whom are managers of conservation areas (Letter attached).
·  Staff requirements in MMA/SBF and FUNAI do not include profiles for IL/IP and biodiversity conservation respectively
·  Staff requirements in MMA/SBF and FUNAI include profiles for IL/IP and biodiversity conservation respectively
Funai employees are participating in all the PNGATI training courses. The PNGATI Cerrado course is being organized and funded by Funai, and held its first module in June, 2015.

Agreed-upon standards and limits for use of forest resources
The joint Working Group on IL and conservation area overlap presented a report of its activities, mapping all instances of overlap.

description.narrative: 9. Existence of surveillance and monitoring plans with standards and practices defined to support the implementation of ethno zoning and plans

comment.narrative:
Only ILs that were part of PPTAL in the Amazon have surveillance and monitoring protocols and carry out inspection activities in ILs but these do not contain environmental monitoring nor are they related to specific ethno- zones and their goals
ILs in other forest biomes do not have surveillance and monitoring protocols and only have Indigenous Surveillance (observation) Stations that are not related to zoning

All the IL reference areas have established surveillance Protocols and undertaken environmental monitoring
50% of the ILs composing the network have established Surveillance Protocols and are developing environmental monitoring systems
Although no new specific regulations have been created, monitoring and surveillance of ILs is an ongoing activity for Funai, in colaboration with Ibama.

description.narrative: A network of ILs modeling environmental management practices for conservation in different forest biomes is in place and is being effectively managed by the indigenous peoples and organizations
10. Number of ethno-management plans in ILs that are:

comment.narrative: see data below
see data below

Through a letter of agreement with Anai-Bahia, ethnomanagement plans were developed for the reference areas Entre Serras and Caiçara/Ilha de São Pedro (Northeast Region). These were presented during a three-day seminar held in Paulo Afonso (Bahia), April 7-10, 2015 (see http://us3.campaign-archive1.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=71b7f2feba&e=4a987eb951). At the present moment, therefore, 8 of the project reference areas have ethnomanagement plans completed (Mamoadate, Igarapé Lourdes, Wajãpi, Galibi, Jumina, Uaçá ILs already had ethnomanagement plans).
The project surveyed gray literature and other sources, identifying another 45 existing ethnomanagement plans in other ILs (as well as a few other plans that cover a portion of an IL).
The project assisted Funai in establishing a new technical cooperation project with UNDP (BRA/13/019) to help implement PNGATI and apply resources from the Fundo Clima/MMA-Ministério do Meio Ambiente, The project assisted in drafting the public call for proposasl for ethnomanagement plans (PGTAs) in the Caatinga and Cerrado biomes (R$ 2.8 million), launched in August 2014. Of the 15 proposals selected, 4 are project reference areas (Bakairi, Xerente, Xacriabá and Corrego João Pereira ILs), and were written with the help of project consultants. Through a Letter of Agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN) the project assisted in the initial training of the organizations carrying out the proposals (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=65d3e8bace&e=4a987eb951).
Also with the assistance of ISPN, the project launched a call for small projects in the reference areas, and Taunay-Ipegue IL approved a project for ethnomapping.
Project consultants are carrying out ethnomapping workshops in Bracui IL (Rio de Janeiro) as part of an ethnomanagement plan. In Mangueirinha IL (Paraná), the project held a three-day workshop to discuss ethnomanagement, including one day of ethnomapping (see http://us3.campaign-archive1.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=e8a23d4715&e=4a987eb951).
Through partnership with TNC, training of youths in ethnomapping was carried out in Trincheira-Bacajá IL.
The project signed a letter of agreement with the Comissão Pró-Índio/Acre to carry out the revision of Mamoadate IL´s ethnomanagement plan.
The basic tools of ethnomanagement, ethnomapping and ethnozoning, are being discussed in all the PNGATI training courses (see for example http://us3.campaign-archive1.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=502428d96a&e=4a987eb951)

description.narrative: developed and tested

The project assisted in the establishment of a new technical cooperation project (BRA/13/019) between Funai and UNDP, signed in December 2013, to help implement PNGATI and apply resources from the Fundo Clima/MMA-Ministério do Meio Ambiente, The project assisted in drafting the public call for proposal for ethnomanagement plans (PGTAs) in the Caatinga and Cerrado biomes (R$ 2.8 million), launched in August 2014. Of the 15 proposals selected, 4 are project reference areas (Bakairi, Xerente, Xacriabá and Corrego João Pereira ILs), and were written with the help of project consultants. Through a Letter of Agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN) the project is assisting in the initial training of the organizations carrying out the proposals (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=65d3e8bace&e=4a987eb951)
The project assisted Funai and MMA in drafting the Fundo Amazonia/BNDES call for PGTA proposals - R$ 70 million (published in 08 May 2014) and helped the Andirá-Marau IL, a reference area, to prepare its proposal, in partnership with the Centro de Trabalho Indigenista (CTI). The proposal was approved, along with a proposal by CPI/Acre, which will benefit Mamoadate IL, another reference area.

Ibirama IL (SC) approved a small project to produce of seedlings of the jussara palm (Euterpe edulis) for replanting in areas where this species has been decimated by extraction of palm hearts, building on and expanding the microproject.
In Mangueirinha IL (Paraná), indigenous leaders expressed concern with harvesting levels of erva maté and other forest products, and suggested carrying out an inventory of these resources. The project brought leaders to Brasília to discuss inclusion of Mangueirinha IL in the National Forest Inventory, carried out by the Serviço Florestal Brasileiro with GEF funding, through FAO (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=c20c4bfa0c&e=4a987eb951)

Through a letter of agreement, the Centro de Desenvolvimento Agroecologico Sabia, carried out agroecological and agroforestry extension in 3 reference areas in the Northeast region, training youths as multipliers (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=29a8d98645&e=4a987eb951)
In collaboration with the Projeto Warana Agroecologia, the project helped organize the 1st Fair of Seeds, Flavors and Knowledge in the Andirá-Marau IL (Amazonas). See:http://us3.campaign-archive1.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=5bee8f2c3f&e=4a987eb951
The project is currently supporting an 8-module extension course in Agroecology with the three Terena reference areas in Mato Grosso do Sul (Cachoeirinha, Lalima and Taunay/Ipegue), in collaboration with the Universidade Estadual do Mato Grosso do Sul - Campus Glória de Dourados. The first module was held in June 2015, and the following modules will be held in the second semester of 2015.
Through an agreement with the Instituto Sociedade, População e Natureza (ISPN), indigenous organizations in project reference areas presented proposals to a small grants program, with 37 proposals approved (see http://us3.campaign-archive2.com/?u=37099afc6b3fe6c9fbcec7684&id=e236a7b66e&e=4a987eb951). A number of the projects have agroecology as their focus.

comment.narrative: (C) SNC;
(D) TNC.

The Rede CLIMA has been playing an important role through the participation in discussions regarding climate modelling activities and emission factors for the GHG Inventory. All these activities have also been responsible for the consolidation of this network as a pivotal partner of the implementation of the UNFCCC in Brazil. Moreover, the TNC document was available for the public consultation, from October 2014 to January 2015, with the involvement of experts and representatives of civil society. To strengthen the institutional capacity building for education, training and public awareness related to climate change, it is planned for next months to hold a workshop to release and discuss the results presented in TNC.

description.narrative: Sector and regional vulnerabilities to climate change have been assessed using improved methodologies and climate models.
(A) Status of â€œBrazilian Global Model of the Climate System (MBSCG);

comment.narrative: (A) SNC (no Brazilian Global model, only Eta/CPTEC regional model);
(A) MBSCG developed and Eta/CPTEC model improved with higher resolution for a larger domain;

The Global Model of the Climate System (MBSCG) and the Eta/CPTEC regional model were improved with higher resolution for a larger domain. The coupled ocean-atmosphere version of the Brazilian Earth System Model (BESM) - former MBSCG - was implemented and tested in the supercomputer Tupa, installed at INPE. This version of BESM is able to generate scenarios of global climate change for present time up to 2100.
However, a preliminary analysis, identified the need for improvements in some used models. Now it is necessary to investigate these gaps and needs more accurately, a process that will now rely on the recent entry of Brazil in the Earth System Grid Federation (ESGF) through INPE.
In order to enhance the country’s data assessment and management capacities, which are critical to facilitate BESM’s developing process, after a comprehensive survey, INPE proposed that the Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation of Brazil (MCTI) financed the Institute’s insertion in the Earth System Grid Federation (ESGF), a ultra-scale data network that provides state-of-the-art online communication for the exchange of information among specialists that are contributing to BESM’s completion.
Thus, along with the acquisition of the equipment and software required to make Brazil one of the ESGF world nods, a specialist was hired to design and present workshops aimed at training INPE and other institutions’ researchers and public managers in this new tool. Currently, INPE resarchers are already using the ESGF-INPE platform and the second workshop is being planned by the consultant and the TCN’s Coordination team.

description.narrative: (B) Detailed climate change scenarios based on MBSCG and regional Eta model;

comment.narrative: (B) Limited climate change scenarios generated under SNC;
(B) Higher number (at least 4) climate change scenarios generated under TNC;

Climate scenarios for the next 100 years, based on the RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 and HadGEM scenarios, generated by BESM and used by the IPCC in its AR5, prepared by experts in climate modeling of the Rede CLIMA.

description.narrative: (C) Climate change impact assessment for key sectors (agriculture, water resources, energy, megacities and urban areas, biodiversity, human health);

comment.narrative: (C) Limited CC impact assessment has been prepared under SNC;
(C) Improved CC impact assessment has been prepared under TNC;

All Terms of Reference prepared by Rede CLIMA sub-networks supported the hiring of consultants who worked under each sub-network coordination analysing data generated through the scenario. The reports were evaluated by INPE senior researchers and compiled into a single document describing each sectorial vulnerabilities.

description.narrative: (D) Mapping of vulnerability of key sectors and regions to climate change impacts.

comment.narrative: (D) Inadequate insight in key V&A sectors due to limitations of data and methodologies under SNC.
(D) Improved insight in key V&A sectors due to improved data and methodologies under TNC.

All Terms of Reference prepared by Rede CLIMA sub-networks supported the hiring of consultants who worked under each sub-network coordination analysing data generated through the scenario. The reports were evaluated by INPE senior researchers and compiled into a single document describing each sectorial vulnerabilities.

The team of experts and consultants involved in the Third National Communication has been mobilized in order to define, along with the MCTI press office, the activities that will result in the publication in different media of all outputs contained in the TNC. Data platform for the GHG Inventory was finished and it is in validation and test stage.

The sector responsible for institutional communications is supporting the activities needed to TCN publication. Moreover, the translation of the document has been already started and the bidding process for the graphic service is in course.
